critique: The document is an executive order from 1933 related to employing citizens in public works projects during the Great Depression. It authorizes the attachment of Coast Guard warrant officers to the War Department for duty in connection with public works projects and the Civilian Conservation Corps. It prioritizes these officers over members of the Army, Naval, and Marine Corps Reserves. The order seems to expand executive power by utilizing existing departments and agencies to address unemployment. It also centralizes control at the federal level. There is no clear indication of ideological tilt, immigration approach, national security vs. civil liberties, or social inclusion. The economic regulation aspect is interventionist, as it involves the government in employing citizens in public works.
